VISITOR VISA (B-1 / B-2 / B-1/B-2) Purpose: Short visits for business (B-1), tourism/medical/family (B-2), or both (B-1/B-2 combined). Eligibility Criteria: Applicant’s visit must be temporary (typically under 6 months). Applicant must have a residence outside the U.S. they do not intend to abandon. Must demonstrate ties to home country (employment, family, property, etc.). Must show financial ability to cover expenses during stay. Cannot seek or accept employment in the U.S. Must have a valid passport (generally 6 months beyond intended stay). Must not have violated U.S. immigration laws previously. Documents Required: DS-160 confirmation page MRV (visa) fee receipt Interview appointment confirmation Passport-sized photo Supporting evidence (bank statements, job letters, etc.) 2. STUDENT VISAS (F-1, M-1, J-1) Purpose: For studying at approved U.S. institutions (academic, vocational, or exchange programs). Eligibility Criteria: Must have a Form I-20 (F/M) or DS-2019 (J) from a SEVP-approved institution. Must show proof of financial resources to cover tuition and living costs. Must have sufficient English proficiency or enroll in English training. Must maintain a residence abroad with no intention of permanent immigration. Must intend to study full-time at the institution. Notes: Dependents (spouse/children) can apply for F-2 / M-2 / J-2 visas. J-1 may include exchange categories like scholars, researchers, or interns. 3. WORK VISAS (H-1B, L-1, O-1, TN, etc.) H-1B (Specialty Occupations) Job must require specialized knowledge (usually bachelor’s degree or higher). Employer must file a Labor Condition Application (LCA) with the Dept. of Labor. Applicant must have the necessary qualifications and degree equivalence. L-1 (Intra-company Transfer) Applicant must have worked 1+ year abroad for a qualifying employer. Transfer must be to a parent, branch, affiliate, or subsidiary in the U.S. O-1 (Individuals with Extraordinary Ability) Must demonstrate national/international recognition in science, art, business, athletics, etc. TN (USMCA/NAFTA) For citizens of Canada or Mexico with qualifying professional occupations. 4. IMMIGRANT VISAS (Green Card Pathways) Common Categories: Family-based: Immediate relatives of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents. Employment-based: Skilled workers, professionals, investors (EB-1 to EB-5). Diversity Visa (DV Lottery): Randomly selected individuals from underrepresented countries. Eligibility Factors: Valid petition (Form I-130, I-140, etc.) approved by USCIS. No disqualifying criminal or immigration violations. Medical examination clearance. Proof of financial sponsorship (Form I-864 for family-based). 5. VISA WAIVER PROGRAM (VWP) For: Nationals of 40+ approved countries. Duration: 90 days or less (tourism/business only). Requirements: Must have ESTA authorization prior to travel. Must hold e-passport valid for at least six months beyond intended stay. No prior visa overstays or ineligibility grounds. 6. GENERAL INELIGIBILITY GROUNDS (Section 212 INA) Applicants are ineligible if they: Have overstayed or violated prior U.S. visa terms. Have certain criminal convictions (drug, moral turpitude, etc.). Pose security, health, or public charge risks. Have engaged in immigration fraud or misrepresentation . 7. KEY REFERENCES USCIS Policy Manual – Volume 2: Nonimmigrants U.S. Department of State – Visa Types Overview [8 U.S.C. §1182 (INA §212)] – Inadmissibility Criteria
